titleStmt.title: འཕགས་པ་གདན་བཞི་པའི་རྣམ་པར་བཤད་པ།
'phags pa gdan bzhi pa'i rnam par bshad pa/
Ārya­catuḥpīṭha­ṭīkā
An Explanation of the “Tantra in Four Parts”

notesStmt.note: Last updated at 07/09/2018 at 10:01:22 by admin

Szánto (2008) comments on the authorship of the text, quoting the colophon as saying: "These [chapters of the commentary] to three pīṭhas were written by the practitioner Kalyāṇavarman who thought compassionately of sentient beings. It is said that when [he was writing] the introduction to this [last] pīṭha the ḍākinīs forbade [him to continue]. Or, it is said that just when he was about to begin the commentary [to the fourth pīṭha] he met the ḍākinī(s) face to face and thus achieving realization he disappeared. Hence [I], the Indian upādhyāya Smṛtijñānakīrti, have begun writing a commentary to the fourth pīṭha of the Catuṣpīṭha according to what I have heard from my consecrated masters." Szánto adds that Smṛtijñānakīrti's addenda to Kalyāṇavarman's text, i.e. his own commentary to the fourth pīṭha, was most likely written directly in Tibetan.

Although the Tibetan translators translated “pītha” as _gdan_, Szánto (2012) notes that the word pītha in the title of the root tantra does not refer to locations (or “sacred sites”), but rather sub-chapters or parts of a text.
